this quite briefly so what is clean architecture um essentially uh it is a
way of architecting your apps and your Solutions uh that is often displayed
like this so you start off with your domain uh and it's it's often portrayed in this this kind of onion pattern you
start off with your domain in the middle and the domain contains Enterprise logic and
types surrounding the domain you have the application layer and the application layer contains business
logic and types what's the difference the difference is that uh the application layer contains logic and
types specific to this application okay so theoretically your domain might be more
broad surrounding these you have the presentation layer and the infrastru
layer now the whole point of this is that all the dependencies point inwards okay so presentation is dependent on
application application is dependent on domain infrastructure is dependent on application uh and domain is is not
dependent on anything external in a nutshell and and that's um
you know there are obviously lots of caveats all of that but in a nutshell this is the the core principle of clean
architecture is that all the dependencies flow only in One Direction this is a really good way of architecting your apps in.net uh and to
just just give you the key bullet points it gives you applications that are independent of Frameworks testable
independent of UI independent of database and independent of anything external okay so all of the dependencies
flow inwards which means that because the dependent the the domain isn't dependent say on the database you can
change the domain without those concerns and it lets you basically build an application
that's maintainable and it's going to last you a long time so that's it in a nutshell as I said if you want to learn more about clean architecture plenty of

the drve principle okay so the drive principles don't repeat yourself it
states every piece of knowledge must have a single unambiguous authoritative
representation within a system there are in my opinion two key
words here right there are two words that stand out that are the most important and anyone guess what I think
they are un ambiguous and authoritative y
those are definitely good choices yeah um I would I would pick
knowledge and authoritative and the reason that this is important right is that knowledge means something very
specific specific right so when we're saying don't repeat yourself and we're saying don't have code in more than one
place that knows how to do something okay now knowing how to do something
means effectively how to change the state of your solution or how to perform
a specific algorithm it doesn't mean things like properties okay and I'm
